update.description:
This PR adds:

* The `Step` feature to the `Playback` class
* The integration test for it

The internal structure of the Implementation class has been slightly restructured in order to pave the way for the next feature to be implemented: `Seek`.

* Both the `Batch` and its iterator are now owned by the Implementation class, and generated at the moment of the creation of the object \(no need to `std::move`them\).
update.title: Step playback

content.raw: Thanks to you. Looks good to me, then.
content.html: Thanks to you. Looks good to me, then.

content.raw: Thanks for the heads up! I wasn’t aware the repo had a Windows CI. I just sent a fix to the test and asked Javier to re-run the test in Jenkins. It’s no longer failing.
content.html: Thanks for the heads up! I wasn’t aware the repo had a Windows CI. I just sent a fix to the test and asked Javier to re-run the test in Jenkins. It’s no longer failing.

content.raw: You’re right! I just created issue #93 to keep track of this
content.html: You’re right! I just created issue #93 to keep track of this

content.raw: There’s one error on Windows [here](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/686/) on one of the expectations of your test. Sometimes could be timing due to the `sleep_for`.
content.html: There’s one error on Windows here on one of the expectations of your test. Sometimes could be timing due to the sleep_for.

content.raw: One idea for a future pull request could be to add support for `pause`, `step`, `resume` using `ign log playback`. We normally try to offer CLI support for the main features. It would be a great complement to this pull request.
content.html: One idea for a future pull request could be to add support for pause, step, resume using ign log playback. We normally try to offer CLI support for the main features. It would be a great complement to this pull request.

content.raw: @caguero just finished addressing your comments. This is ready for another pass.
content.html: @caguero just finished addressing your comments. This is ready for another pass.

content.raw: done, thanks!
you’re right, done!
done, thanks!
oops, forgot about this. done, thanks!
done, thanks!

update.description:
This PR adds:

* The `Step` feature to the `Playback` class
* The integration test for it

The internal structure of the Implementation class has been slightly restructured in order to pave the way for the next feature to be implemented: `Seek`.

* Both the `Batch` and its iterator are now owned by the Implementation class, and generated at the moment of the creation of the object \(no need to `std::move`them\).
update.title: Step playback

content.raw: sure, done!
I didn’t know this, thanks for pointing it @sloretz ! I just did a quick test to verify it and is exactly as you suggested :\)
content.html: I didn’t know this, thanks for pointing it @sloretz ! I just did a quick test to verify it and is exactly as you suggested :)

content.raw: `this->WaitUntil(...)`? See other similar calls.
That’s great, nothing to do, then.
is `nextMessageTime` a bit clearer if it refers to the next message?
content.html: is nextMessageTime a bit clearer if it refers to the next message?

I haven't tested, but I'm pretty sure any time duration unit with less precision than nanoseconds will automatically convert without a std::chrono::duration_cast. I would expect the following to work as the code currently is

using namespace std::chrono_literals;
playback->Step(4s);

content.raw: Consider to pass the parameter as a reference.
content.html: Consider to pass the parameter as a reference.

content.raw: Consider to pass the parameter as a reference.
content.html: Consider to pass the parameter as a reference.

content.raw: Add `\return`?
Should we pass a reference instead for efficiency?
content.html: Should we pass a reference instead for efficiency?

content.raw: I wonder if we could change the `std::chrono::nanoseconds` to `chrono::duration<Rep,Period>`. This way is more generic and the user can use any preferred time units. See [http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/thread/this\_thread/sleep\_for/](http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/thread/this_thread/sleep_for/) for an example.
content.html: I wonder if we could change the std::chrono::nanoseconds to chrono::duration<Rep,Period>. This way is more generic and the user can use any preferred time units. See http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/thread/this_thread/sleep_for/ for an example.

content.raw: Thanks for the review @caguero , I just finished addressing your comments. Could you PTAL?
content.html: Thanks for the review @caguero , I just finished addressing your comments. Could you PTAL?

content.raw: for sure, done!
done, thanks!
sure, done!
sure, done!
